questions.question: Match the following: a. Bernard soulier syndrome 1. antibodies to, the metalloprotease ADAMTS13 b. Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia 2. absence of the platelet Gp Ib-IX-V receptor c. Hemolytic uremic syndrome 3. absence of the platelet Gp IIb/IIIa receptor d. Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura 4. Escherichia coli O157:H7
questions.explanation: thrombasthenia 3. absence of the platelet Gp IIb/IIIa receptor c. Hemolytic uremic syndrome 4. Escherichia coli O157:H7 d. Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura 1. antibodies to, the metalloprotease ADAMTS13 Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia (absence of the platelet Gp IIb/IIIa receptor) and Bernard-Soulier syndrome (absence of the platelet Gp Ib-IX-V receptor). Both are inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion and present with bleeding symptoms in childhood. Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura : The pathogenesis of inherited (Upshaw-Schulman syndrome) and idiopathic TTP (ITTP) is related to a deficiency of, or antibodies to, the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which cleaves VWF. VWF is normally secreted as ultra-large multimers, which are then cleaved by ADAMTS13. The persistence of ultra-large VWF molecules is thought to contribute to pathogenic platelet adhesion and aggregation Therapeutic plasma exchange (TPE) remains the mainstay of treatment of TTP. TPE is continued until the platelet count is normal and signs of hemolysis are resolved for at least 2 days. Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is a syndrome characterized by acute renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia. It is seen preceded by an episode of diarrhea, often hemorrhagic in nature, predominantly in children. Escherichia coli O157:H7 is the most frequent etiologic serotype. Atypical HUS (aHUS) is usually due to genetic defects in complement genes or antibodies directed against complementary regulatory proteins that result in chronic complement activation. Reference: Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine 24 th Edition, Page 408, 409, 971, 1285 www.researchgate.net/publication/341932348_Bernard_Soulier_Syndrome

questions.question: Match the following: a) Hemophilia A 1. Factor IX deficiency b) Von-Willebrand disease 2. Factor XIII deficiency c) Osler weber rendu disease 3. Factor VIII deficiency d) Laki lorand factor 4. Arteriovenous malformations e) Hemophilia B 5. Von willebrand factor deficiency
questions.explanation: Osler weber rendu disease 4. Arteriovenous malformations Laki lorand factor 2. Factor XIII deficiency Hemophilia B 1. Factor IX deficiency 1. Von Willebrand Disease : Autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in vWF, a large protein that promotes the adhesion of platelets to subendothelial collagen and stabilizes factor VIII Type 1 and type 3 von Willebrand disease are associated with quantitative defects in vWF Type 1, an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by a mild to moderate vWF deficiency. It is associated with point substitutions that interfere with maturation of the vWF protein or that result in rapid clearance from the plasma. Type 3 disease is an autosomal disorder usually caused by deletions or frameshift mutations resulting in little to no vWF synthesis. Because vWF stabilizes factor VIII in the circulation, factor VIII levels are also reduced in type 3 disease and the associated bleeding disorder is often severe. Type 2 von Willebrand disease is characterized by qualitative defects in vWF ; there are several subtypes, of which type 2A is the most common . It is inherited as an autosomal dominant disorder. 2. Hemophilia A , the most common hereditary disease associated with life-threatening bleeding, is caused by mutations in factor VIII , an essential cofactor for factor IX in the coagulation cascade. Hemophilia A is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait and thus affects mainly males and homozygous females. Patients with hemophilia A have a prolonged PTT and a normal PT, results that point to an abnormality of the intrinsic coagulation pathway. Factor VIII–specific assays are required for diagnosis Hemophilia A is treated with infusions of recombinant factor VIII. 3. Hemophilia B (Christmas Disease, Factor IX Deficiency) Severe factor IX deficiency produces a disorder clinically indistinguishable from factor VIII deficiency it is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait The PTT is prolonged and the PT is normal. Diagnosis of Christmas disease is possible only by assay of the factor levels. The disease is treated with infusions of recombinant factor IX. 4. Osler weber rendu disease / Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT) is characterized by the presence of multiple arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) that lack intervening capillaries and result in direct connections between arteries and veins. The most common clinical manifestation is spontaneous and recurrent nosebleeds (epistaxis) beginning on average at age 12 years. Telangiectasia (small AVMs) are characteristically found on the lips, tongue, buccal and gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa, face, and fingers. 5. Factor XIII (FXIII) deficiency / Laki lorand factor deficiency is a rare bleeding disorder that presents with symptoms spanning from delayed umbilical cord separation to intracranial hemorrhage. FXIII plays a pivotal role in stabilizing clots and facilitating the cross-linking of the fibrin polymer, thereby ensuring effective hemostasis The acquired FXIII deficiency typically arises from factors such as hyperconsumption, hemodilution, and decreased synthesis and is more prevalent than the congenital form. questions.question: A 34-year-old male is being treated for tuberculosis with rifampin, isoniazid, and pyrazinamide. He has been on this regimen for the past 4 weeks. Over the last few days, he has noticed easy bruising, petechiae on his legs, and gum bleeding. He denies any history of trauma and he does not have any signs of active bleeding. On examination, he has petechiae on his extremities and ecchymosis. Laboratory tests show: Platelet count: 45,000/µL (normal range: 150,000–450,000/µL) Hemoglobin: 13.5 g/dL (normal) White blood cell count: Normal Peripheral blood smear: No signs of platelet clumping, but reduced platelet count Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: for tuberculosis treatment, which strongly suggests drug-induced thrombocytopenia . Drugs can induce thrombocytopenia through direct effects on platelets and secondary to immunologically mediated platelet destruction. The drugs most commonly implicated are quinine, quinidine, and vancomycin, all of which induce drug-dependent antibody binding to platelet glycoproteins. Clinically, these patients present with moderate to severe thrombocytopenia, and spontaneous bleeding varying from simple ecchymoses, petechiae and mucosal bleeding to life-threatening spontaneous intracranial hemorrhage. There are two types of drug-induced thrombocytopenia: immune and nonimmune. If a medicine causes your immune system to produce antibodies which seek and destroy your platelets, the condition is called drug-induced immune thrombocytopenia . Heparin , a blood thinner, is the most common cause of drug-induced immune thrombocytopenia. If a medicine prevents your bone marrow from making enough platelets, the condition is called drug-induced non immune thrombocytopenia . Chemotherapy drugs and a seizure medicine called valproic acid may lead to this problem. Other medicines that cause drug-induced thrombocytopenia include: Furosemide Gold, used to treat arthritis Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) Penicillin Quinidine Quinine Ranitidine Sulfonamides Linezolid and other antibiotics Statins Rifampin Treatment The first step is to stop using the medicine that is causing the problem. For people who have life-threatening bleeding, treatments may include: Immunoglobulin therapy (IVIG) Plasma exchange (plasmapheresis) Platelet transfusions Corticosteroid medicine Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) (Option A) :HIT is a well-known cause of thrombocytopenia that occurs after exposure to heparin . It is caused by the formation of antibodies against the heparin-platelet factor 4 complex , which activates platelets and leads to thrombosis and thrombocytopenia . Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) (Option C) :ITP is an autoimmune disorder in which the body's immune system produces antibodies against platelets, leading to destruction of platelets in the spleen. The most common presenting symptoms are petechiae , easy bruising , and gum bleeding . Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (Option D) : The classic findings of DIC include low platelet count , prolonged PT and aPTT , increased D-dimer , and organ dysfunction (e.g., renal or liver failure).

questions.question: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fatigue, jaundice, and dark urine. A blood film reveals: The patient has a history of dapsone use for the management of a skin condition.Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the bite cell formation in this patient?
questions.explanation: deficiency , as indicated by the presence of bite cells and polychromasia on the blood film following exposure to dapsone. This condition leads to the premature destruction of red blood cells and resultant haemolytic anaemia. Bite Cells: Bite cells are normal-sized red blood cells with a characteristic appearance, resembling cells with a 'bite' taken out of their membrane. Oxidative Haemolysis and Bite Cell Formation: Causes : Defects in red blood cell enzymes, particularly glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Exposure to oxidative drugs such as dapsone and sulfasalazine. Oxidative damage causes RBC destruction via: Intravascular hemolysis (IVH): RBCs lyse directly in circulation. Extravascular hemolysis (EVH): Damaged RBCs are recognized and destroyed by macrophages in the reticuloendothelial system (RES) (e.g., spleen). Mechanism : G6PD deficiency makes red blood cells susceptible to oxidative damage. Under oxidative stress, haemoglobin denatures, forming Heinz bodies that adhere to the membrane. Spleen macrophages attempt to remove Heinz bodies, resulting in the formation of bite cells. Identifying Bite Cells and Diagnosing Oxidative Haemolysis: Blood Film Findings : Presence of bite cells. Blister cells: Red blood cells with blistering on the membrane. Irregularly shaped small cells. Polychromasia: Increased young red blood cells (reticulocytes) indicating heightened red cell production. Diagnostic Tools : Supravital stain (e.g., methyl violet) to visualize Heinz bodies . Measuring G6PD levels to confirm deficiency : Meth Hb reduction test. Clinical Significance of Bite Cells: Bite cells indicate oxidative

options.C: Normal aPTT and PT with decreased vWF levels

Von-Willebrand Disease It is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor (vWF), a glycoprotein crucial for platelet adhesion and stabilizing factor VIII in the coagulation cascade. Functions of vWF: Platelet Adhesion: Mediates binding of platelets to subendothelial collagen at sites of vascular injury. Stabilization of Factor VIII: Protects Factor VIII from degradation, prolonging its half-life. Clinical manifestation: Superficial bruising, epistaxis, menorrhagia and gastrointestinal haemorrhage Excessive haemorrhage might only be observed after trauma or surgery Heavy menstrual bleeding Might first manifest with dental extractions, particularly wisdom tooth extraction, or tonsillectomy Investigation: Types aPTT vWF antigen vWF activity FVIII activity Multimer Inheritance 1 Normal or ↑ ↓ ↓ ↓ Normal distribution, decreased in quantity Autosomal dominant 2A Normal or ↑ ↓ ↓↓ ↓ Loss of high- and intermediate-MW multimers Autosomal dominant 2B Normal or ↑ ↓ ↓↓ ↓ Loss of high-MW multimers Autosomal dominant 2M Normal or ↑ ↓ ↓↓ ↓ Normal distribution, decreased in quantity Autosomal dominant 2N ↑↑ Normal or ↓ Normal or ↓ ↓↓ Normal distribution Autosomal recessive 3 ↑↑ ↓↓ ↓↓ ↓↓ Absent Autosomal recessive In general, increase in aPTT and BT, but normal PT and platelet count. (Option A) Treatment: Desmopressin (DDAVP) Tranexamic acid or epsilon-aminocaproic acid for mucosal bleeding or non-serious bleeding Factor VIII concentrates for serious or persistent bleeding Bleeding in type 3 patients responds only to factor VIII/vWF concentrate Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 909, 910

questions.question: A 9-year-old boy is scheduled for a dental extraction. He has a history of recurrent epistaxis and prolonged bleeding when he is hurt. His parents are first cousins. Physical examination shows petechiae. The dentist was worried about the medical history and ordered blood investigations as follows: Tests Results aPTT, PT, and ristocetin cofactor activity Normal Bleeding time Increased Light transmission aggregometry (LTA) Altered platelet aggregation with ADP Normal aggregation with ristocetin. Flow cytometry Defective expression of alpha IIb beta 3 integrin Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment to prevent bleeding during the procedure?
questions.explanation: consistent with Glanzmann Thrombasthenia, a congenital platelet disorder characterized by defective platelet aggregation due to a lack of Gp IIb/IIIa receptors (aids in platelet-platelet adhesion). rFVIIa is helpful for patients who are undergoing surgery or are refractory to platelet transfusions as it enhances thrombin generation at the site of vascular injury and can promote hemostasis despite platelet dysfunction. Glanzmann Thrombasthenia Congenital bleeding disorder History of high consanguinity in marriage of the parents Pathology: Autosomal recessive inheritance Mutations involving chromosome 17 Absence of the platelet Gp IIb/IIIa receptor These receptors are essential for platelet aggregation and hemostasis Clinical Features: Lifelong mucocutaneous bleeding episodes Epistaxis is very common in children Gingival bleeds Gastrointestinal bleeding Menorrhagia Investigations: Tests Results aPTT, PT, and ristocetin cofactor activity Normal Bleeding time Increased Light transmission aggregometry (LTA) (gold standard test) Altered platelet aggregation with ADP, collagen, and epinephrine. Normal aggregation with ristocetin. Flow cytometry Defective expression of alpha IIb beta 3 integrin Molecular genetic tests Gene mutations in ITGA2B or ITGB3 Treatment: Therapy Clinical setting Desmopressin Mild bleeding (Option A ruled out) Platelets and/or recombinant activated clotting factor VII (rFVIIa) Surgery prophylaxis Tranexamic acid Mucocutaneous bleeding (Option B ruled out) Recombinant FVIIa Platelet refractoriness cases Platelet transfusions have the risk of alloimmunization. So, HLA-matched single donor platelets for transfusion are preferred. Fresh frozen plasma (Option D): It is used to replace clotting factors in coagulopathy disorders (e.g., liver disease, disseminated intravascular coagulation). FFP does not contain platelets and would not address the platelet dysfunction seen in Glanzmann Thrombasthenia. This option is incorrect. Reference: Glanzmann Thrombasthenia - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 908, 909 pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3437135/#:~:text=Platelet%20transfusion%20was %20the%20hallmark,of%20patients%20to%20be%20performed.

questions.question: Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome is suspected in a 3-year-old boy who has eczema, gingival bleeding, and recurrent respiratory tract infections. His mother also noticed blood in his stools. What test would confirm the diagnosis of this syndrome?
questions.explanation: patients with Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, there is either a deficiency or absence of WASP protein due to mutations in the WASP gene. This test is highly specific for WAS and is commonly used to confirm the diagnosis of Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome. Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome X-linked recessive Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is caused by mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23 that encodes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP) Pathology: Mutations in the WASP gene affect T lymphocytes and other lymphocyte subsets i.e. dendritic cells, and platelets WASp regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus plays an important role in many lymphocyte functions, including cell adhesion and migration and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting and target cells Severely dysfunctional platelets, and thrombocytopenia Immunodeficiency Clinical manifestation: Recurrent bacterial infections Eczema Bleeding Associated with IBD - Colitis Increased risk of development of malignant lymphoma Investigation: IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are usually normal. Paradoxically the levels of IgA and IgE are often elevated Blood smear reduced-sized platelets Diagnosis is made by expression of intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASp) in blood cells. There is defective or absent WAS protein. (Option C) Treatment: Prophylactic antibiotics Immunoglobulin G (IgG) supplementation Topical treatment of eczema Serum immunoelectrophoresis (Option A): This test evaluates the levels of different immunoglobulins (IgG, IgM, IgA, IgE). In Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, there may be low levels of IgM, which supports the diagnosis of immunodeficiency. However, this test alone is not diagnostic for WAS. This option is incorrect. Platelet function assay (Option B): In Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, the platelets are small and dysfunctional, contributing to bleeding tendencies. While this test can show abnormal platelet function in WAS, it is not specific to confirm the diagnosis. This option is incorrect. Complete blood count (CBC) with differential (Option D): Thrombocytopenia is seen in Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome. However, they are not specific enough to confirm the diagnosis. This option is incorrect. Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 842, 907, 2472, 2716 Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis Of Disease 10th edition page 246
